H0.text: They would die within hours is what would most likely happen to the plants if a deadly disease infected the hummingbird population, because those plants rely on hummingbirds for pollination.

H1.text: They would become endangered for the plants that rely on hummingbirds for pollination if a deadly disease infected the hummingbird population.

H2.text: They would need to migrate if a deadly disease infected the hummingbird population, because some plants rely on hummingbirds for pollination.

H3.text: They would grow at a slower rate if a deadly disease infected the hummingbird population that pollinates them.

A4.text: Despite the dire predictions, the theorised decline in pollinators has had no effect on food production, with yields of both animal-pollinated and non-animal-pollinated crops increasing at the same rate, over the period of supposed pollinator decline.

A5.text: Seven out of the ten most important crops in the world, in terms of volume, are pollinated by wind (maize, rice and wheat) or have vegetative propagation (banana, sugar cane, potato, beet, and cassava) and thus do not require animal pollinators for food production.

A6.text: Apomixis occurs in many plant species such as dandelions (Taraxacum species) and also in some non-plant organisms.

A7.text: Plants that use insects or other animals to move pollen from one flower to the next have developed greatly modified flower parts to attract pollinators and to facilitate the movement of pollen from one flower to the insect and from the insect to the next flower.
